G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify custody and parenting provisions of a judgment when the moving party demonstrates (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The Bristol County Probate and Family Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 209, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as well as continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting orders relating to the minor child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Bristol County Probate and Family Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 209, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as well as continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting orders relating to the minor child.

G.L. c. 209.proposition: The Bristol County Probate and Family Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 209, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as well as continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting orders relating to the minor child.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Since the entry of the March 15, 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law governing custody modifications.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: This case concerns modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, not modification of custody. While it does articulate the general Massachusetts standard that a party seeking modification must show a material change in circumstances since the earlier judgment, that standard is applied in the context of support/alimony, not custody. Using this case to support a proposition specifically about custody-modification standards is therefore inaccurate and overextends the holding.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Since the entry of the March 15, 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances as that term is used in Massachusetts law governing custody modifications.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards and findings required when making an initial custody award in a divorce judgment, focusing on the best interests of the child and the need to weigh all relevant factors. It does not address the Massachusetts standard for *modification* of an existing custody judgment or what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances.’ Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about post‑judgment custody modifications.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Father’s conduct reflects a breakdown in the joint legal custody arrangement with respect to educational decision-making, in that the parties can no longer effectively share decision-making authority regarding school attendance and related educational supports.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses joint custody as "joint decision making" and explains that it is inappropriate where parents are highly antagonistic and fundamentally disagree about major child-rearing issues including schooling and education. The court affirms the trial judge’s conclusion that, because of these deep disagreements, joint custody (i.e., shared decision-making responsibility) would be "an invitation to continued warfare and conflict." This squarely supports the proposition that the father’s conduct and the parties’ conflict reflect a breakdown in any joint legal custody arrangement regarding educational decisions and related supports.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. … Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Father’s conduct reflects a breakdown in the joint legal custody arrangement with respect to educational decision-making, in that the parties can no longer effectively share decision-making authority regarding school attendance and related educational supports.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns initial allocation of custody (joint legal, sole physical) and a relocation request, not a later breakdown of joint legal custody regarding education. The court notes the statutory definition of joint legal custody, including educational decisions, but makes no findings of conflict, impasse, or inability of the parents to share decision‑making; indeed, it finds they “can communicate in regard to the children.” Thus it does not support a proposition that the father’s conduct shows a breakdown of joint legal custody over educational decision-making.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ … The husband and wife are responsible and can communicate in regard to the children.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The circumstances described herein were not contemplated by the parties or the Court at the time of the March 15, 2021 Judgment and constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances warranting modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether unforeseen post‑judgment circumstances amount to a substantial and material change justifying modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Mason v. Coleman is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, addressing the standard for permitting relocation where parents share joint physical custody and applying a best‑interests analysis, not the ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ standard for modifying a prior judgment. The opinion does not discuss § 28, modification standards, or unforeseen circumstances relative to an earlier judgment, so it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents where one of the parents seeks to relocate without the consent of the other parent. Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests…. We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children….”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The circumstances described herein were not contemplated by the parties or the Court at the time of the March 15, 2021 Judgment and constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances warranting modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The case concerns an appeal from an initial custody judgment and the need for explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence; it does not involve a later modification proceeding, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 208, § 28 or the standard for a ‘substantial and material change in circumstances.’ The opinion addresses how courts must weigh domestic violence in original custody determinations and the requirement of written findings under G.L. c. 208, § 31, not whether new, unforeseen post‑judgment circumstances warrant modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about changed circumstances justifying modification under § 28.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: In any modification of a custody or parenting order, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly affirms that the paramount consideration in custody determinations is the best interests/welfare of the child, but this discussion is in the context of initial custody awards (and of standards under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a)), not modification proceedings. The court expressly declines to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modifications under §20, and it does not state that in modification actions the only or paramount standard is best interests. Thus, while the case is solid authority on best interests as the controlling standard in custody decisions generally, it does not specifically support the proposition as framed for modifications.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history... The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865... and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: In any modification of a custody or parenting order, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards in care-and-protection/guardianship-type disputes, emphasizing parental unfitness and the child’s welfare, but it does not articulate the broad rule that in any modification of a custody or parenting order the paramount consideration is the child’s best interests. Instead, it frames the controlling question more narrowly as whether the child’s welfare would be seriously endangered if custody is not transferred from the parent. Thus, it is related to but does not clearly state or adopt the general ‘paramount best interests’ formulation for all custody modifications.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … The controlling question is whether the welfare of this child would be seriously endangered if custody is not transferred from the mother.”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that stable and consistent school attendance and appropriate educational support are integral to a child’s best interests and overall welfare.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses stability, consistency, and developmental/therapeutic supports as components of Hugo’s best interests, but it does not specifically address school attendance or educational support in the sense suggested by the proposition. References to education are limited to Ms. J.’s efforts to identify appropriate educational placement and to the statutory requirement to provide ‘suitable support and education,’ without developing any broader legal principle about school stability as integral to a child’s welfare. Thus, the case does not clearly establish the claimed Massachusetts legal rule regarding stable school attendance and educational support.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt:
He also credited her testimony that, as Hugo advances to the age of formal schooling, it will be important to minimize his developmental deficits so that he can interact with peers and teachers to optimize his continuing growth and development.
...
General Laws c. 210, § 6, requires the judge to be satisfied that one who petitions for adoption be of ‘sufficient ability to bring up the child and provide suitable support and education’ before he issues a decree of adoption.

*Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*.raw_text: *Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*, 397 Mass. 659 (1986)
*Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that stable and consistent school attendance and appropriate educational support are integral to a child’s best interests and overall welfare.
*Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*.case_name: Petition of the Department of Social Services to Dispense With Consent to Adoption
*Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness, the social-worker privilege, and the balance between protecting confidential relationships and protecting children’s welfare in adoption/termination proceedings. It does not discuss school attendance, educational stability, or educational support as components of the child’s best interests. The case recognizes a child’s right to a stable and safe environment generally, but not specifically in the educational context the proposition describes.
*Petition of the Dept. of Social Servs.*.relevant_excerpt: “In proceedings where the ability of natural parents to provide and care for their children is called into question, ‘the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents.’ … If the exception is interpreted to permit disclosure of information relevant to the fitness of the parents and the best interests of the children only by a social worker who actually brings a petition … the interest of protecting children … will be defeated.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: The parties’ inability to agree on and consistently implement decisions relating to Emily’s school attendance and tutoring demonstrates that joint legal custody with equal decision-making authority regarding education is no longer workable or in Emily’s best interests.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: This opinion is about relocation and the statutory rights of an unmarried mother with sole legal custody before paternity is adjudicated. It does not address joint legal custody, decision‑making regarding education, or conflicts over school attendance and tutoring. Nothing in the reasoning or holding concerns the workability or best interests analysis of joint legal custody, so it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition stated.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "This matter begins and ends with statutory interpretation. The paternity statute... makes unmistakably clear that the mother is the sole legal parent of a nonmarital child from the moment of the child’s birth until the establishment of the putative father as a legal parent... At the time she relocated with the child, neither the putative father nor the Commonwealth had any legal authority to interfere with or review the mother’s decision."

*Herbst v. Herbst*, 2007 Mass. App. Unpu.raw_text: *Herbst v. Herbst*, 2007 Mass. App. Unpub. LEXIS 1038
*Herbst v. Herbst*, 2007 Mass. App. Unpu.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently applied this standard in custody and parenting time modifications, requiring that a prior judgment be altered when circumstances have changed so significantly that adherence to the existing order would no longer promote the child’s best interests.
